summary: The document is a memorandum from Brian Latell, Director of the Center for the Study of Intelligence, to the Director and Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, discussing the JFK Review Board's actions on CIA records related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. It outlines a disagreement between the Directorate of Operations (DO) and the Center for the Study of Intelligence (CSI) regarding the release of names of two CIA employees who retired under covert status. The DO argues for the protection of these individuals' identities due to potential physical danger and operational security risks, while the CSI, after consultation with the Office of General Counsel (OGC), recommends against appealing the Review Board's decision to release the names, citing lack of clear and convincing evidence of danger to the individuals.
key_findings: The JFK Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) has decided to release 16 CIA documents from Lee Harvey Oswald's 201 file, including the names of two covert CIA employees.
The DO opposes the release of the two employees' names, citing risks to their safety and operational security.
The CSI, consulting with OGC, finds the DO's argument insufficient to warrant Presidential intervention to block the release.
The document highlights the tension between transparency and national security concerns in the context of historical records release.
keywords: Center for the Study of Intelligence
